Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: Dexterous Manipulation with Underactuated Hands: Strategies, Control Primitives, and Design for Open-Source Hardware

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work will contribute to the fundamental understanding of dexterous manipulation, especially in how low-dimensional hands that have traditionally been used for pure grasping tasks can be leveraged for excellent manipulation capabilities. The PI team will investigate how the passive mechanics of compliant and underactuated hands can be utilized for manipulation strategies include vibrational stick-slip, equilibrium point manipulation, and finger gaiting, as well as develop low-level planning and control schemes to implement those for a wide range of manipulation movements. This work will lead to the development of general-purpose robot hands having low-dimensional actuation and sensing. Furthermore, the focus on design for open-source dissemination through rapid prototyping techniques will result in novel fabrication strategies in furtherance of fast innovation in a range of fields.

A key thread of the proposed work is that simple hand designs and control schemes will be made freely available through an open-source repository. The hands will be able to be easily and inexpensively fabricated with rapid prototyping techniques, lower the entry barrier from expense hand hardware and encouraging continual design improvements. Additionally, the team will kick-start a user community around those hands through an on-site tutorial at Yale for approximately 20 students and postdocs from top manipulation research groups. For the education and outreach component of this proposal, a major thrust involves enhancing RoboticsCourseWare.org, the PI's open-access repository for robotics teaching materials, in order to highlight open-source and other inexpensive hardware platforms for educational purposes. A strong focus on involving a diverse group of undergraduates and high school students in the research plan is also highlighted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to investigate ways to make robotic systems much more dexterous, and in ways that are practical for real-world applications. Approaches started with mechanically simple underactuated hands that are more durable, lighter weight, and much less expensive than traditional hand designs, but more importantly, are able to function effectively in the presence of the kinds of uncertainty about the properties of objects or the environment that are characteristic of real-world human environments. Having previously shown highly effective performance in grasping objects (i.e. acquiring them), this project sought to begin to investigate one of the most important next steps in robotic manipulation - manipulating grasped objects within the hand to enable tasks to be performed with them such as using a tool or inserting a key into a lock.

Major outcomes and contributions of this project related to its intellectual merit include: thorough demonstration of the effectiveness of underactuated hands to perform dexterous within-hand manipulation functionality, facilitated by their ability to self-reconfigure even after grasping, which also allows for large uncertainties in sensing to be passively accommodated; extensive study of fingertip-based within-hand manipulation, including design optimizations and experimental demonstrations; formulation of a new concept we call “caging-based within-hand manipulation” in which the hand keeps the object constrained from dropping while shaping the hand to reorient the object within a wrap grasp;  development of a simple visual-servoing approach to fingertip manipulation that is effective even without detailed information about the object or hand properties; exploration of the mechanics of within-hand manipulation within the framework of parallel mechanisms analysis; detailed examination of human hand usage during daily tasks to motivate and benchmark robotic hand function; formulation of approximately 10 new hand design concepts that facilitate within-hand manipulation. More than 40 peer-reviewed journal and conference papers were published based on work on this award.

Major outcomes and contributions of this project related to its broader impact include: release of six complete robot hand designs as open-source hardware through the Yale OpenHand Project; development of methods to fabricate robust hands easily and inexpensively using 3D printing; hosting two workshops on the design and fabrication of those open-source hands; development and dissemination of a standard set of objects and high resolution RGBD scans of those for benchmarking in robotic grasping and manipulation.
